questions.text: In the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, the grey kit consists of __________
questions.solution:
In the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, the grey kit consists of T.Azithromycin and T.Cefixime

The color coded packs are as follows:

  • Kit 1– Grey, for urethra discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis.
  • Kit 2– Green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3– White, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4– Blue, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 5– Red, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 6– Yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7– Black, for inguinal bubo

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

questions.text: You are tasked with conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic statuses?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Kuppuswamy scale
  • Radhukar scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Shirvastava scale
  • Bharadwaj scale
  • Kulshestra scale
  • Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamyâ€™s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: An entomologist was studying a vector and the pathogen it transmits. He found that the pathogen underwent changes in number and morphology in the vector. What is this type of biological transmission called?
questions.solution:
This type of biological transmission where a pathogen undergoes a change in number and morphology in a vector is called cyclo-propagative transmission.

Malaria is a disease whose causative organism (Plasmodium sp.) undergoes cyclo-propagative transmission. In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in the Anopheles mosquito (vector).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon and sweet corn, candies and syrupy foods

questions.text: The given image depicts:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a frequency polygon.

Note:

A line graph depicts a time-trend and has time as the x-axis. In the given graph above, the x-axis is the value of Hb concentration.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: What is the surveillance reporting system used by the WHO?
questions.solution:
The surveillance reporting system used by the WHO is the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

The WHO collects and disseminates epidemiological information on diseases subject to International Health Regulations. It is done through an Automatic Telex Reply Service (ATRS) and the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except:
questions.solution:
Health education is an element of primary health care, not a pillar.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
The minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines is 4 weeks.

This is because decreasing the interval between two doses may interfere with the antibody response and protection. Thus, live vaccines can either be given on the same day according to the schedule or 4 weeks apart.

Note: In Park 25th ed. the minimum interval between two live vaccines is given as 3 weeks. However, several other standard sources including CDC and UNDP suggested an interval of 4 weeks. When both are given in options, it is recommended to mark 4 weeks as the correct answer.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding of dactylitis along with the shrunken spleen is suggestive of sickle cell disease.

In sickle cell disease, repeated splenic micro-infarcts cause loss of splenic function and shrinkage. Vaso-occlusion causes hand-foot syndrome with painful infarction of the digits and dactylitis.

Other manifestations include:

  • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, needing emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis leading to isosthenuria
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
Anti centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man with a history of smoking, hypertension, and chronic exertional angina develops severe daily episodes of chest pain. An electrocardiogram shows ST depression. However, on cardiac evaluation, there is no increase in the levels of cardiac biomarkers. What could be the most probable diagnosis of the patient?

Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction- NSTEMI

ST-elevation myocardial infarction- STEMI
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina.

Unstable angina is the chest discomfort or pain due to insufficient blood flow and oxygen to the heart. It occurs due to the development of the thrombus on a pre-existing disrupted atherosclerotic plaque and is non-occlusive. The patients develop chest pain radiating to the jaws or arms and shortness of breath. 

An electrocardiogram may show hyperacute T-wave, T-wave flattening, inverted T-waves, and ST depression in unstable angina. Unstable angina is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers. If cardiac biomarkers are elevated in these patients, then the diagnosis of myocardial infarction is considered.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) includes:

  • Unstable angina(UA)
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI)
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

Other options:

Option A- NSTEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there are ST-segment depression and deep T-wave inversions. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in NSTEMI unlike in unstable angina.

Option B- STEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there is ST-segment elevation with T-wave changes. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in STEMI.

Option C- Left heart failure results due to dysfunction of the left ventricle leading to insufficient delivery of the blood to vital organs. The electrocardiogram shows non-specific ischemic changes, left ventricle hypertrophy or arrhythmias. The cardiac biomarker like brain natriuretic peptide may be elevated.

questions.text: A patient in the emergency ward rolls around on the bed in a futile attempt to find a position free from pain. This attitude of the patient is most likely to be because of
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is most likely to be due to renal colic. A patient of renal colic would have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain and tries to find a pain free position.

On the contrary, a patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and also has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain in peritonitis.

A patient of acute pancreatitis usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain. A patient of meningitis would have neck stiffness.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department after a suicide attempt in which an unknown quantity of metformin was ingested. On biochemical examination, her lactate levels are raised. What is the type of lactic acidosis encountered here?
questions.solution:
Metformin (biguanide) toxicity encountered here is a Type B lactic acidosis.

Lactic acidosis is defined as an increase in plasma lactate levels. The various types of L-lactic acidosis are:

  • Type A - This occurs secondary to poor tissue perfusion. The conditions include shock, cardiac failure, severe anemia, carbon monoxide, or cyanide toxicity.
  • Type B - This type of lactic acidosis occurs in aerobic disorders. It can occur secondary to malignancies, renal failure, hepatic failure, drugs like metformin, ethanol, ethylene glycol, and methanol, diabetes mellitus, seizures, Severe malaria/ cholera etc .

Note: A D-lactic acidosis is an unusual form of metabolic acidosis that occurs in patients with short bowel syndrome, post-jejunoileal bypass, or intestinal obstruction. This is due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to blow-off a paper repeatedly while doing an EEG. The recording shows symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Absence seizures. Hyperventilation provokes it.

The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begin and end suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background.

An absence seizure is characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. The seizures can occur hundreds of times per day, but the child may be unaware of or unable to convey their existence.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.solution:
Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to mutations in the WASP gene. The characteristic triad of features is:

  • Eczema
  • Thrombocytopenia - along with decreased platelet size, impaired platelet aggregation response
  • Immunodeficiency - low IgM, high IgE, defective regulatory T cells causing recurrent bacterial infections.

Option B: Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) is an autosomal recessive disease due to mutations in CHS1/LYST gene (defective lysosomal transport). It leads to recurrent pyogenic infections, partial oculocutaneous albinism, neurologic abnormalities, and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral smear shows large azurophilic granules in neutrophils and eosinophils. It can lead to hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.

Option C: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with severe thrombocytopenia (diagnosed at birth) and bilateral absent radii (thumbs are always present).

Option D: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with oculocutaneous albinism, bleeding diathesis (deficient dense granules in platelets), pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is
questions.solution:
The temperature of the water bath for a patient with frostbite should be maintained between 40-44°C.

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vasoconstriction. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Initial treatment is rewarming, which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 40°–44°C (104°–111° F).

Massage, application of ice water, and extreme heat are contraindicated.

The injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Analgesics are often required during rewarming. Antibiotics are used if there is evidence of infection.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Fluent aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Option B: Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C: Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D: Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur suggest that the condition could be Marfan syndrome, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant mode. The family pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are tall and have an decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers. Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches may be present.

Associated cardiovascular abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans.

It is a skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.

The causal mechanism is due to the secretion of epidermal growth factor in the region involved. It can be benign or malignancy-associated.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is often associated with obesity or insulin resistance, it is common and usually mild.

Malignancy associated acanthosis nigricans is much less common. It is usually associated with gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and uterine carcinoma.

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis

questions.text: What is the finding in the given EEG of an infant?
questions.solution:
Hypsarrhythmia is an abnormal interictal pattern which consists of diffuse, giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves. During the clinical spasm, there is a marked suppression of the EEG background (the electrodecremental response).

Hypsarrhythmias are usually seen in epileptic spasms. These are characterized by a briefly sustained flexion or extension of predominantly proximal muscles, including truncal muscles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.

It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus.

The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration.

Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below.

Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below.

Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely associated with the condition seen in this CT image of a 32-year-old male?
questions.solution:
Berry aneurysm is commonly associated with polycystic kidney disease. The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the age of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with adult polycystic kidney disease (PKD).

The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%. Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following tests helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease from irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Assessment of fecal calprotectin levels helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. Hence, they are often assessed to distinguish the two conditions. These tests are also done to check if the disease is active and to detect postoperative recurrence.

questions.text: The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes all of the following symptoms except:
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Profuse sweating
  • Palpitation (due to tachycardia)

Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is associated with AV block.

Causes of AV block:

Autonomic:

  • Carotid sinus hypersensitivity

Metabolic:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypermagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency

Drug related:

  • Beta blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Adenosine
  • Digitalis
  • Lithium
  • Class 1 and class 3 anti arrhythmics

Infections:

  • Endocarditis
  • Lyme disease
  • Chaga's disease
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Diphtheria
  • Toxoplasmosis

Inflammatory:

  • SLE
  • RA
  • Scleroderma

Infiltrative:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemachromatosis

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.solution:
The murmur of HOCM increases on standing.

Standing decreases the preload and it leads to an increase in the obstruction and intensity of the murmur.

The murmur of HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. S1 is normal, S2 may show paradoxical splitting, and S4 is heard.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect
Inspiration (↑venous return to right atrium) ↑ intensity of right sided sounds
Hand grip (↑afterload ) ↑ intensity of MR, AR and VSD murmurs
↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
MVP: delayed onset of click / murmur
Valsalva-Phase II, standing up (↓ preload) ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur
Rapid squatting (↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)		 ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
↑ intensity of AS, MR and VSD murmurs
MVP: later onset of click / murmur

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of obstructive lung disease.

Common pulmonary function tests (PFTs) include

  • Spirometry
  • Measurement of lung volumes
  • Quantitation of diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide(DLCO)

Based on PFTs, lung disorders are broadly classified into:

  1. Obstructive disease
  2. Restrictive disease
  3. Pulmonary vascular disease

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Rosenbach sign - Pulsations of the liver
Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen
Muller sign - Systolic pulsations of uvula

questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen. Traube's sign is a pistol shot sound heard over femoral arteries. 

Aortic regurgitation (AR). 

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly are called Gerhardt’s sign. (Option B)
  • Rosenbach sign is seen in AR where pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy. (Option C)
  • Systolic pulsations of uvula is known as Muller's sign. (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

  • In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. The symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output can be managed by diuretics and vasodilators.
  • In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:
    • The patient is symptomatic
    • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
    • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

questions.solution:
Burkitt's lymphoma is associated with the following chromosomal abnormalities:

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Meningioma is not commonly seen in MEN2B Syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is associated with meningiomas.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules.

They occur in areas subjected to repeated trauma such as the forearm or Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. 

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pericarditis, mitral regurgitation
  • Pleuritis, interstitial lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

Related Pearl: Most commons conditions in Rheumatoid Arthritis

M/C extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules
M/C pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
M/C cardiac involvement Pericarditis
M/C valvular lesion Mitral regurgitation
M/C hematologic abnormality Normochromic, normocytic anemia
M/C part of the spine involved Cervical spine
M/C type of lymphoma Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
M/C cause of death Cardiovascular disease

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with complaints of urinary incontinence. His history is notable for increasing forgetfulness and the physical examination reveals an abnormal gait. His fundus looks normal, he has no tremors.  Which of the following conditions is it most likely to be?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Normal pressure hydrocephalus. 

The triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (Adam’s/Hakim’s triad):

  • Dementia
  • Ataxia (gait disturbance) or apractic
  • Urinary incontinence

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. Timely diagnosis and prompt intervention can lead to the reversal of symptoms in NPH.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (Hakim-Adams syndrome):

  • It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.
  • Caused by conditions producing scarring of basilar meninges
  • Communicating hydrocephalus is seen
  • Adam’s / Hakim’s triad (as mentioned above)
  • Papilloedema is not seen.
  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures may appear propped open (so-called “boxcarring”), which can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy.
  • Treatment - Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting
  • CSF parameters are normal usually

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cefotaxime is the drug of choice in this patient.

This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).

SBP is a common and severe complication of ascites characterized by spontaneous infection of the ascitic fluid without an intraabdominal source.

The most common organisms are Escherichia coli and other gut bacteria.

The diagnosis of SBP is made when the fluid sample has an absolute neutrophil count >250/μL.

The first line of empiric treatment is with a third-generation cephalosporin because the majority of cases are caused by aerobic gram-negative microbes such as E. coli, with cefotaxime being the most commonly used antibiotic.

In patients who have had an episode(s) of SBP and recovered, once-weekly administration of antibiotics is used as prophylaxis for recurrent SBP.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who is a known hypertensive, not on treatment, presents to the OPD for a regular checkup. On examination, his blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The presence of which of the following in him will help us diagnose metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP- ATP III?

choices.text: Triglycerides of 100 mg/dL and waist circumference of 105 cm
Waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL
Fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL and HDL cholesterol of 60 mg/dL
HDL Cholesterol of 60 mg/dL and triglycerides of 100 mg/dL

questions.solution:
In this patient with the blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg,Â waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL helps diagnose metabolic syndrome.Â 

Metabolic syndrome is present ifÂ three or moreÂ of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (males), >88 cm (females)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level â‰¥Â 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure â‰¥130 mmHg systolic or â‰¥Â 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level â‰¥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: The image of the hands of a patient is given below.  This sign is seen in
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly).

Other options:

  • Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin

Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Eyelid erythema/ heliotrope rash in dermatomyositis-

V- sign in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Gottron papules in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

questions.text: While taking ward rounds, you come across the ECG of a patient which looks as given below. Which of the following can cause such an ECG?
questions.solution:
In the above ECG, there is a depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, a slightly prolonged PR interval, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia, which can be seen when giving insulin infusion due to the intracellular shift of potassium. 

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Other options:

Option A: Vit A can cause hypercalcemia. It will show a shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration in ECG. 

Option B: Bisphosphonate overdose is associated with hypocalcemia. It shows prolongation of the QT interval due to lengthening of the ST segment. The QT interval prolongation is proportional to the degree of hypocalcemia. The T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Below image shows prolonged QT interval in hypocalcemia

Option C: ACE inhibitors cause hyperkalemia.

ECG changes in hyperkalemia. Different changes are seen according to the levels of potassium.

  • Tall peaked T waves are present when the serum potassium levels are 5.5–6.5 mmol/L. 
  • Loss of P waves are seen when the concentration is between 6.5–7.5 mmol/L.
  • Widened QRS complex is seen when the concentration is between 7.0–8.0 mmol/L
  • Sine wave pattern when concentration is >8.0 mmol/L

Below ECG- hyperkalemia

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the mucocele of the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The gall bladder is easily palpable in mucocele.

  • Mucocele is due to prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct usually by a large solitary calculus.
  • Obstructed GB lumen is progressively distended by mucus or by a clear transudate produced by mucous epithelial cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • A visible, easily palpable, non-tender gall bladder
    • Frequently remains asymptomatic.
  • Treatment: early cholecystectomy

questions.text: Not true regarding the condition in the given image?

choices.text: Incomplete cyst wall removal causes recurrence
A punctum may not always be visible

questions.solution:
The image shows an infected sebaceous cyst(epidermoid cyst) as evident by the inflammation of the swelling. Malignancies in epidermoid cysts are very rare. 

Other options: 

Incomplete removal of the cyst wall is indeed a frequent cause of recurrence

Punctum is not always clinically visible as it can be buried

Injection of triamcinolone Perilesionally aids faster resolution & clearing of infection. But this does not cause the eradication of cyst 

 

The most common site of a Sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

Treatment depends on the clinical state of the cyst. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially, total surgical excision should be done once the inflammation has subsided.

questions.text: What is the drug used for estrogen dependant breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers in pre-menopausal women.

It exhibits selective agonistic and antagonistic activity for ER receptors:

  • Agonist activity at uterus, bone, liver, and pituitary
  • Antagonist activity at breast and blood vessels

Uses:

  • Primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women
  • Reducing the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast
  • Reducing the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in ipsilateral and contralateral breasts

Dose: 20 mg once daily for 10 years (Earlier 5 years was the duration, but latest guidelines recommend 10 years).

Adverse effects:

  • Hot flushes (most common)
  • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Thromboembolic events
  • Reduced visual acuity, cataract, and retinal deposits.

questions.text: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long standing non-pitting edema in the limbs.

Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues.

Usually, there is a balance between fluid formation and lymph transport capacity. With congenital hypoplasia or acquired obstruction, there is a reduction in transport capacity resulting in the accumulation of fluid and protein in the interstitium. 

This along with cellular debris and waste products of metabolism elicit an inflammatory response associated with fibrovascular proliferation and collagen deposition. This leads to firm, non-pitting swelling characteristic of chronic, long-standing edema.

Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb elevation, external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be considered.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55mm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

Primary survey is used to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control haemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood - FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit.
  • Radiographs of the cervical spine, chest AP view and pelvis AP view are done when necessary.
  • When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A surgeon while performing a laparotomy procedure uses the following instrument. Which of the following option is true about this instrument?

choices.text: Safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Monopolar electrocautery. Both cutting and coagulation modes are possible with monopolar electrocautery.

  • Application of Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms is responsible for the cutting of tissues.
  • Application of High voltage current for a short duration(intermittent waveform) is responsible for the coagulating of tissues

A short circuit is established in bipolar electrocautery between the tips of the instrument. This makes the chances of burns lesser compared to monopolar electrocautery. Bipolar electrocautery has less lateral dissipation of current so it is safer in procedures closure to vital structures. 

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.

Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes:

  • Excessive loss of sodium
  • Decreased intravascular volume
  • Low blood pressure
  • Circulatory collapse

Primary causes of Addisonian crisis include:

  • Adrenal haemorrhage
  • Acute infection

Secondary causes of Addisonian crisis include:

  • Surgery
  • Cessation of steroid therapy
  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is performed for tumors less than 4 cm in size. It is also performed for:

  • Bilateral RCC
  • Carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney
  • RCC in one kidney and hydronephrosis or calculi in the contralateral kidney

Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. 

Radical nephrectomy is indicated in:

  • Large tumors
  • When partial nephrectomy is not feasible 

RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also indicated in advanced/ metastatic tumors. 

Debulking surgery has a role in patients with distant metastasis. mTOR inhibitors such as Everolimus, IL-2 agents, sunitinib, and sorafenib have also been found to be useful as adjuvant therapy in RCC.

Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.solution:
Intercostal tube is placed along the upper border of the lower rib, in order to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle.

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  • Above the level of the nipple
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space.

The technique includes the following:

  • Meticulous attention to sterility throughout.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers, these should only be the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other.
  • Drain is placed in a short tunnel to reduce the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base. The drain should pass over the upper border of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. The retaining stitch should be secure but should not obliterate the drain.
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is vital for pneumothorax management but should be omitted if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  • Connect the drain to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check that the drain has achieved its objective by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: The following barium swallow is suggestive of
questions.solution:
Image shows markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing).

In achalasia cardia, the lower esophagral spinchter (LES) is hypertensive and fails to relax appropriately in response to swallowing. Sphincter spasm and delayed emptying through LES are also seen. Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of esophageal achalasia.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

questions.text: Identify the condition seen in this X-ray.
questions.solution:
This X ray shows a typical finding of multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract which is indicative of Pneumatosis intestinalis.

It is an uncommon condition where cysts may be located in the subserosa, submucosa, and, rarely, muscularis layer and vary in size from microscopic to several centimeters in diameter.

Pneumatosis not associated with other lesions is referred to as primary pneumatosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the image given below?

choices.text: It is also known as thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
Donor site can be reused before healing

questions.solution:
The image given depicts the harvesting of a split skin graft. The donor site can not be reused before healing.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • Presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is contraindicated in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donor to full thickness defect.

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
The given cannula is 20 gauge IV cannula as its color code is Pink.

The flow rate in cannula of this gauge is 67mL/minute

questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-Ray of a patient.  Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is characteristic of Pneumoperitoneum which is not seen in Acute intestinal obstruction.

  • The erect X-ray shows gas under both the diaphragms, and the most important cause for this is a hollow viscus perforation.
  • An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome (where the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air)
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively air may be present in the abdomen up to 7 days

Other signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Rigler’s sign: The outer and inner walls of the bowel loop are delineated by gas
  • Football sign/ Air dome sign: A central round air collection seen on a supine x-ray
  • Inverted V sign: Gas is seen on either side of the umbilical ligament

Note:

In an emergency setting, where a patient presents with peritonitis and Xray abdomen confirming pneumoperitoneum, an emergency laparotomy is undertaken to manage the bowel perforation.

questions.text: A surgical consultation is requested for a neonate currently in the neonatal intensive care. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

  1. Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 
  2. Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus, hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing tortuous swelling over the scalp and the clinical findings are suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm.

Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. The superficial temporal artery is most commonly involved.

Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.

Angiography is the investigation of choice.

Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascular occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cause carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide causes bladder cancer. 

The risk of bladder cancer is related to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.

Carcinoma of the bladder & associated risk factors: 

Histological subtype Risk factors
Transitional cell carcinoma (urothelial)
  • Smoking
  • Exposure to aniline dyes
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Pelvic irradiation

Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Chronic irritation caused by stone disease
  • Bladder diverticula
  • Chronic UTI
  • Smoking
Adenocarcinoma
  • Persistent urachus or trigone of the bladder

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about retrosternal goitre?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by neck incision (transcervical). 

Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goitre is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. 

Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goitre
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

For a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

Option C: Blood supply to retrosternal goitre is from the thyroid vessels (secondary).

questions.text: True statement about intermittent claudication:

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles because of the involvement of the superficial femoral artery in chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day.

Rest pain signifies critical limb ischemia, occurring due to the worsening of perfusion to the muscle.

Related Pearl: Ankleâ€“brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The highest pressure is in the dorsalispedis, posterior tibial or peroneal artery that serves as the numerator, with the highest brachial systolic pressure being the denominator.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.5 Rest pain
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Freyâ€™s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome.

Freyâ€™s syndromeÂ is also known asÂ Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops post parotid surgery or other surgeries that cause an opening of the parotid capsule. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres, along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region.Â 

Clinical features as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of foodÂ include:

  • Sweating
  • Warmth
  • Redness of the faceÂ 

Diagnosed using a starch-iodine test. Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated in management but is often not curative. The symptoms can be managed by the subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and the use of antiperspirant.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.solution:
A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. 

Usually in normal persons, there are numerous loops of gas-containing small bowel located centrally in the abdomen. But, in some conditions like small bowel obstruction, fluid replaces the air-filled lumen. This appears as a paucity of gas on abdominal radiography and is known as a gasless abdomen. 

Patients with acute pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen.

Other causes include:

  • Bowel ischemia
  • Congenital atresia
  • Ascites
  • Gastroenteritis
  • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement
  • Post-surgery following total colectomy, oesophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior resection
  • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults

questions.text: Dohlmanâ€™s  procedure is  for:
questions.solution:
Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker’s diverticulum.

It is a transoral endoscopic approach, that ablates the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Related Pearl: Zenkerâ€™s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: False statement regarding Meckelâ€™s diverticulum is______.

choices.text: Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic mucosa seen.
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in children.

questions.solution:
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in adults with Meckel’s diverticula. Bleeding is the most common manifestation in children.

Related Pearl: Rule of twoâ€™s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Location 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It isÂ usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals.Â It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extentÂ when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

questions.text: A 3 week old patient presenting with vomiting and failure to thrive is found to have pyloric stenosis. What should be the next step of management?

choices.text: Its emergency so do pyloromyotomy immediately

questions.solution:
Correction of electrolyte disturbances is the next step of management.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a medical emergency not a surgical emergency. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet, leading to nonbilious, projectile emesis, loss of hydrochloric acid with the onset of hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and dehydration. Immediate treatment requires correction of fluid loss and electrolytes imbalance.

  • An initial fluid bolus( 20mL/kg) of crystalloids should be infused immediately if infant is dehydrated.
  • Infants should receive 1.5 -2 times maintenance iv fluids: 150 - 180 ml/Kg/day of 0.9% saline with 0.15% Kcl in 5% glucose.
  • Definitive treatment  : Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: An anxious patient with a black mole over his back presents to the clinic for evaluation. All of the following features according to the ABCDE rule will point towards a diagnosis of melanoma in this patient except?
questions.solution:
D stands for diameter >6 mm and not depth > 6mm.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings suggestive of melanoma

The ABCDE of Melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape.

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill defined.

C : Color variegation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color.

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser).

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammography which was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is to follow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years.

During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Annual screening
2 Benign finding Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding 6 monthly mammogram for next 2 years
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy—proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the swelling lifting the ear lobe is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma is a painless, slowly growing, benign tumor that usually affects females more than males. It most commonly arises from the superficial lobe. It is unicentric in origin with a pseudo-capsule present.Â It is a radioresistant tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures
  • With no facial nerve involvement

In case of deep lobe involvement,Â tonsils and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which gets obliterated eventually.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormality depending on the part of a duct that is persistent.
    • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
    • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical polyp or sinus.
    • Persistence of distal end with mucus retention leads to cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by means of a fibrous band.
    • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image given is of a Morris retractor, which is a large retractor useful for providing maximum exposure in large incisions e.g., abdominal incisions.

It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

Related Pearl: Identification of different retractors

Deavers Retractor

Doyen's retractor

Morris retractor

Czerny’s retractor
