questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of endometriosis?

choices.text: Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy
Asymptomatic patients are observed over 6â€“8 months without any need of the infertility workup
Estrogen is the drug of choice for endometriosis
Not all symptomatic women need treatment

questions.solution:
Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy. This is the only true statement.

Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Minimal asymptomatic cases are to be observed over 6–8 months and infertility in such cases should be investigated and treated if necessary.

All symptomatic women do need treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

 Note:

  • Endometrioma is treated by laparoscopic management.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in________.
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is aÂ remnant of the Wolffian ductsÂ in women. These are located in the broad ligamentÂ and the vagina.

The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the level of the internal os where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen.

The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or the vagina. It is called Gartnerâ€™s cyst.Â It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization.Â 

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

Females Embryonal structure Males
Ovary Genital ridge Testis
Ova Primordial germ cells Spermatozoa
Labia majora Labioscrotal swelling Scrotum
Labia minora Urogenital folds Ventral aspect of the penis - penile urethra

 		 Genital tubercle

choices.text: Platypelloid pelvis: has AP diameter > transverse diameter
Gynecoid pelvis:  sacral angle greater than 90 degree
Anthropoid pelvis: high incidence of face to pubis delivery

Platypelloid pelvis has a transverse diameter much larger than the anteroposterior diameter.

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.

It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:

  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
  3. Nuchal translucency (NT)

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur?
questions.solution:
Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

During ovulation, the ovum is released and it enters the fallopian tube. It is propelled towards the uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes. It can only be fertilized within 24 hours of ovulation.  If coitus takes place during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except:

choices.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.solution:
Pansystolic murmur is not a physiological change in pregnancy.

Physiological changes in pregnancy:

Clinical examination

  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • Occasional S3at Mitral area
  • Aortic or pulmonary flow murmurs at aortic/pulmonary areas
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • S1 M increased and widely split

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Pregnancy does not alter voltage
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and
  • Increased left ventricular mass

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cardiotocograph shows sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions.

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Severe fetal asphyxia
  • Severe fetal anemia - Due to anti-D alloimmunization, feto-maternal haemorrhage, bleeding from vasa previa, parvovirus infection and twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Administration of opioid analgesics - pethidine, morphine, alphaprodine, and butorphanol

The pattern is characterized by a stable baseline heart rate between 120-160 with regular sinusoidal oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations is usually between 5-15 beats per minute and accelerations are absent.

Other cardiotocography patterns:

Early deceleration:

Seen in foetal head compression.

Late deceleration:

Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia.  

Variable deceleration:

Seen in umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: The degree of prolapse shown in the image given below is _______
questions.solution: The image shows external os lying at the level of introitus. Hence it is second degree uterine prolapse.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady who had tested positive for HPV  is undergoing an investigation where the following device is used. Which of the following statements is false about this investigation?

choices.text: It is used in lithotomy position
Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy whereÂ the cervix isÂ visualizedÂ at a distance of around 20 cmÂ with the patient in theÂ lithotomy position.

This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?
questions.solution:
MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for the monitoring of fetuses in Rh-negative sensitized mothers.

MCA PSV is enhanced due to increased cardiac output and decreased viscosity of fetal blood. 

If the MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM (multiples of the median) and the gestational age is less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered. MCA Doppler PSV has replaced amniocentesis as the preferred test for the detection of anemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in?
questions.solution:
Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths (as shown in the image below). Human papillomaviruses are implicated in causing this condition.

 

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as a crop of small domed vesicles with central umbilication. It is caused by the pox virus and it spreads by close sexual or nonsexual contact and by autoinoculation.

Option C: Chancroid appears as small papules that develop into painful ulcerating pustules. They are associated with unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is caused by H. ducreyi.

Option D: Herpes appears as multiple crops of vesicles and ulcers.

Related Pearl: Different types of inclusion bodies

Inclusion bodies

Virus

Negri bodies

Rabies virus

Torres bodies

Yellow fever

Bollinger bodies

Fowl pox

Guarnieri bodies

Vaccinia

Molluscum bodies

Molluscum contagiosum

Cowdry type A

Herpes and yellow fever virus

Cowdry type B

Adenovirus, poliovirus

Lipschutz bodies

Herpes virus

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. 

Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).

It is managed as follows:

  • Medical - first line of treatment.  
    • NSAIDs
    • Tranexamic acid  
    • OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails 
    • Mirena IUCD
    • Blood transfusion, if required 
  • Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:
    • Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Uterine tamponade
    • Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body. 

Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees:

  • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
  • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
  • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus
  • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved

A central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Immediate caesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation.

Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:

Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery
Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean section

Â Mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:

1st twin presentation Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Caesarean section
Transverse Caesarean section

After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in transverse lie, internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction.

Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech:

  • Interlocking of twins
  • Fetal head trapping above the cervix
  • Umbilical cord prolapse

According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In a case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks.

According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions

questions.text: A G2P1 lady is in the latent phase of labor for 8 hours. The latent phase would be said to be prolonged in her if it lasts for more than _______________
questions.solution:
The latent phase is said to be prolonged in a multigravida if it lasts for more than 14 hours.

Friedman defined prolonged latent phase by:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase 

The first stage of labor consists of two phases :

1) Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change(upto 5 cm of cervical dilatation)

2) Active phase: Follows the latent phase, is characterized by rapid cervical change (3-6 cm)

questions.text: The type of uterine fibromyoma in the image
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Submucous type of uterine fibromyoma.

Uterine myomas are broadly classified into 3 types.

They are-

  • Intramural - remains within the myometrial wall.
  • Submucous - present inside the uterine cavity and covered only by a thin endometrium.
  • Subserous - present towards the peritoneal surface.

Treatment includes:

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid
  • Uterine artery embolization.
  • Myomectomy.
  • Total / subtotal hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: The following ultrasound image signifies:
questions.solution:
The sign is double decidual sign, seen in normal pregnancy, depicting a normal gestational sac.

In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that is outer decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis.

The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac.

This sign can be seen in first trimester transvaginal sonogram.

Other options:

Option A: Intrauterine death- Spalding sign.

Option C: Neural tube defects (spine bifida)- Lemon sign and banana sign.

Option D: Duodenal atresia- Double bubble sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Sign Condition Description
Bagel sign
(USG)		 Tubal ectopic Gestational sac in the adnexa with hyperechoic ring  
Double decidual sac sign
(USG)		 Normal pregnancy Intrauterine gestational sac seen as two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space  
Ball sign
(X-ray)		 Intrauterine fetal death Crumpled up spine of the fetus
Robert’s sign
(X-ray)		 Intrauterine fetal death Presence of gas in the fetal great vessels
Spalding sign
(USG)		 Intrauterine fetal death Overlapping of skull bones after fetal demise
Banana sign
(USG)		 Spina bifida Abnormal anterior curvature of cerebellum
Lemon sign
(USG)		 Spina bifida Inward scalloping of the frontal bones of the calvarium such that the head appears shaped like a lemon

(USG)		 Monochorionic twins Absence of chorionic tissue in the inter-twin membrane 
Lambda sign
(USG)		 Dichorionic twins Chorionic tissue in between the layers of the inter-twin membrane 
Stuck twin sign
(USG)		 Twin to twin transfusion syndrome Smaller twin held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paragard):

It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. 

It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A.

The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

If an IUCD is inserted within 7 days after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is more effective than levonorgestrel/ulipristal acetate regimens.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given vertex presentation is right occipito anterior, where the vertex is occupying the right anterior quadrant of the pelvis.

Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The foetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Succenturiate placenta - One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the given image used for ______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a manual vacuum aspiration syringe, used in manual vacuum aspiration.

It is used for early pregnancy failures or elective termination for up to 12 weeks. A Negative pressure of 660 mmHg is created and products of conception are aspirated.

This procedure takes less time and is less traumatic. It can be done on OPD basis.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

TheÂ Maylard incisionÂ (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transverse and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse Incisions Vertical incisions

Advantages

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less Postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Advantages

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring 

Disadvantages

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination with 2 fingers in the anterior fornix and fingers of other hands behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign:Â Bimanual examination with 2 fingers in anterior fornix and fingers of other hands behind the uterus, abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus which is due to softening of the isthmus.Â 

It is seen during pregnancy at 6-10 wks.

This sign is based on the fact that the upper part of the bodyÂ of the uterus is enlarged by the growing fetus, the lower part of the body is empty and extremelyÂ soft and the cervix is comparatively firm.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination, which is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Clinical Signs in Obstetrics

  • Chadwick’s Sign: Bluish hue to the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall. Seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. The cause is increased blood flow to the pelvic organs. Also known as Jacquemier’s Sign. /
  • Cullen Sign: Bluish discoloration of the skin around the umbilicus. Occurs due to intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Seen in ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Goodell Sign: Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state. Also due to increased blood flow
  • Hegar Sign: An indication of Pregnancy. The softening of the lower parts of the uterus enables the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers on bimanual pelvic examination.
  • Kustner’s Sign: Sign of placental separation. On pushing the uterus upwards does not move the cord with it due to the separation.
  • Ladin’s Sign: Softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix. It occurs at about 6 weeks gestation
  • Osiander’s Sign: Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks. It is a sign of pregnancy
  • Piskacek’s Sign: Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.
  • Schroeder’s Sign: A sign of placental separation. Uterus rises up when the separated placenta is passed downwards
  • Stallworthy’s Sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on the release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign. This sign is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.
  • Turtle Sign: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.
  • Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign: Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus during early pregnancy. It occurs at 5-8 weeks gestation.

questions.text: A young mother presented with dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. Marshall and Bonney's test was positive. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. In this case, the first line of treatment is conservative management.

Stress incontinence is managed as follows:

Conservative management:

  • It is the first line of treatment.
  • It includes:
    • Kegel pelvic floor exercises for 4–6 months
    • Electric/magnetic stimulation for nerve damage, magnetic stimulation
    • Artificial urinary sphincter in neurological condition
    • Vaginal cones
  • It is also done in case surgery fails. 

Medical management:

  • Estrogen cream in menopausal woman
  • Venlafaxine 75 mg daily
  • Imipramine 10–20 mg BD

Surgical management:

  • Kelly's repair - vaginal approach
  • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
  • Burch colposuspension
  • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
  • Slings
    • Tension-free vaginal taping
    • Transobturator taping
  • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
  • Periurethral collagen injection

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with cervical incompetence?

choices.text: Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation
Bleeding per vaginum in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is characterized by repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. Escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of products of conception can also be seen.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix.

Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:

  • Human Papilloma virus (most important)
  • Sexual intercourse before 18 years
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Multiparity
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Smoking and drug abuse
  • Women with STD, HIV, HSV 
  • Immune suppression

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of MgSo4 includes all, except:

choices.text: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach

questions.solution:
MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium.

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach.
  • It blocks neuronal calcium influx.
  • It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate.
  • It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.

questions.text: X-ray of a 10-year-old boy with fever, drooling of saliva and inspiratory stridor is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute epiglottitis. The symptoms of drooling of saliva, inspiratory stridor and fever are suggestive of epiglottitis. The lateral X-ray of neck shows enlarged and edematous epiglottis or “thumb” sign.

Retropharyngeal and parapharyngeal abscess present with neck stiffness, trismus and muffled voice while barking cough and hoarseness are seen in tracheolaryngobronchitis (croup).

Retropharyngeal abscess would show widened pre-vertebral space on X-ray whereas croup is characterized by steeple sign. Parapharyngeal abscess is poorly defined on X ray and is best diagnosed on CT.

Acute epiglottitis

  • Microbiology: Streptococcus > Hemophilus influenzae b
  • Median age: 6-12 years
  • Cinical features: Distress (Inspiratory stidor, tripod positioning), Dysphagia and Drooling
  • X ray findings: Thumb sign (enlarged epiglottis), loss of vallecular space
  • Management: Antibiotics, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

  • Microbiology: viral infection
  • Median age: 6 months to 6 years
  • Clinical features: barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low grade fever
  • X-ray findings: “Steeple sign” due to subglottic narrowing
  • Management: Nebulized racemic epinephrine

Retropharyngeal abscess:

  • Microbiology: Polymicrobial (streptococcus pyogenes, staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes)
  • Median age: 6 months – 6 years
  • Clinical features: Fever, odonyphagia/dysphagia, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice and trismus.
  • X-ray findings: Widened pre-vertebral space
  • Management: Intravenous antibiotics + Surgical drainage, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Parapharyngeal abscess presents similar to Retropharyngeal abscess and is best diagnosed on CT.

Steeple sign – Croup

Widened prevertebral space-Retropharyngeal abscess

Note:

The most common cause of epiglottitis:
In India - Hemophilus influenza.
Rest of the World - Strep. pneumonia.

Though Nelson mentions that H.influenza is not the most common cause of this condition, the latest edition of O.P Ghai still mentions H.influenza as the most common cause of acute epiglottitis. 
What it means is that, in India, even though cases of H. influenza are coming down due to increased vaccine coverage, still H. influenza remains the leading cause of acute epiglottitis in India.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

  • Color; body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate; 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According  to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by:
questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

  1. Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  2. Presence of bipedal oedema
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

  • Gastroschisis: The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
  • Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia: This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The boy in the above clinical scenario has the characteristic features of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

Henoch-SchoÌˆnlein purpura (HSP) is a common small vessel vasculitis in childhood. It is characterized by a purpuric rash and commonly accompanied by arthritis and abdominal pain. About half of the patients with HSP develop renal manifestations, which vary from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

The nephritis associated with HSP usually follows the onset of the rash. The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis appears to be mediated by the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The likely cause in the given clinical scenario is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), in which 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes ambiguous genitalia in females due to increased serum androgens. 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex. It causes pseudohermaphroditism, that is, genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia looks like that of a male.

Note:

  • Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.
  • The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Pseudohermaphroditism of the female child is most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase 17-Hydroxylase 11β-Hydroxylase 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

CP is a static encephalopathy and a disorder of posture and movement often associated with:

  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • Dystonic CP is associated with hypotonia
  • Extrapyramidal CP is associated with ataxia
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

Scissoring gait is a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy as shown in the GIF below-

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to :
questions.solution:
The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin.

Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the oxidation of bilirubin).

Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.

Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools.

Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: It is seen in the first week of life

questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.solution:
Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.

Note:

Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants.

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD by parents for a well-baby checkup when you notice the following lesion. They say the lesion has been present since birth and has been decreasing in size. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots.

Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. Therefore, these spots are congenital, and are easily distinguished from the bruises of child abuse. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

They usually fade away during the first year of life, and the parents should be reassured about this.

 Other options:

  • Salmon patch or naevus simplex is small, pink-colored macules that are commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. They are an ill-defined lesion, which develops due to vascular ectasia. (Note: The subungual oil droplets seen in nail psoriasis are also known as salmon patches).
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis is a congenital benign lesion characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules. The pustular lesions last for 2-3 days, while the hyperpigmented macules may last for about 3 months.
  • Harlequin color change is a congenital lesion, usually seen in low-birth-weight infants where half of the body in the dependent portion turns red in color, while the other half of the body is pale. This occurs due to an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. Changing the infant's position causes a reversal of the pattern.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

10. Hymenal tags

11. Physiological phimosis

12. Conjunctival hemorrhage

13. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A term newborn with no risk factors does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate is 98 beats/minute, no respirations are noted. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A term neonate who remains apnoeic despite stimulation should be given positive pressure ventilation by a bag and mask. 
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV is provided with bag and mask and SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

questions.text: The amount of sodium present in ReSoMal is ________
questions.solution:
Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal) contains 45 mmol/L of sodium.

Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and reduced activity of the sodium–potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

Composition Low-osmolar ORS (mmol/L) ReSoMal (mmol/L)
Glucose  75 125
Sodium  75  45
Potassium  20  40
Chloride  65  70
Citrate  10  7
Magnesium  ---  3
Zinc  --- 0.3
Copper  --- 0.045
Osmolarity (mOsmol/L) 245 300

questions.text: Breast milk is superior to cowâ€™s milk because ________

choices.text: Casein is 60% of the protein content
Whey is 70% of the protein content

questions.solution:
Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The Whey: Casein ratio in human milk fluctuates between 70:30 and 80:20. This ratio is 20:80 in cow's milk. The high fraction of soluble whey protein in breast milk makes it easily digestible.

The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk. Human milk contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine (lacking in cow’s milk), which are necessary for neurotransmission and neuromodulation.

Breast milk is rich in polyunsaturated fat (not saturated fat), which is necessary for myelination. Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid.

Sodium concentration is not high in breast milk. It has a low osmolality, and hence, the solute load on the kidneys is low.

Differences between human milk and cow's milk are shown below:

Nutrient Human milk (per 100 mL) Cow's milk (per 100 mL)
Protein 1.1 g 3.5 g
Calories 67 kcal 73 kcal
Casein 30–40% (rich in whey protein) 80%
Lactose 7.4 g 4.5 g
Fat  3.5 g 4g
Na+ (mEq/L) 6.5 25
K+ (mEq/L) 14 35
Osmolality (mOsm/L) 290 350
calcium/phosphate >2 <2
Vitamin K 1.5 µg 6 µg
Iron 0.29–0.45 mg 0.01-0.38 mg
Vitamin D 0.5-10 IU 0.5-4.5 IU

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.solution:
Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable.

The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method.

Age Head circumference
At birth 33 to 35cm
3 m 40 cm
6 m 43 cm
1 year 46 cm
2 years 48 cm
3 years 49 cm
4 years 50 cm
12 years 52 cm (adult size)
  • Head circumference increases by the following:
    • 2 cm/month in first 3 months
    • 1 cm/month in next 3 months
    • 0.5 cm/month in next 6 months

Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth.

  • At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference
  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.solution:
Among the given fractures, proximal scaphoid fractures are most prone to non-union. 

Since the nutrient artery enters the scaphoid near its distal end, proximal fractures are associated with avascular necrosis and non-union. The more proximal the fracture in the scaphoid, the higher the chances of avascular necrosis and non-union.

Certain bones have a relatively limited or watershed blood supply that can potentially get interrupted by fracture.  These include:

  •  Talar neck
  •  Waist of the scaphoid
  •  Proximal metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal
  •  Femoral neck

Fractures in these sites have a higher risk for non-union or development of osteonecrosis.

questions.text: A maid is playing with a child by spinning him while holding his hands. A few hours later, the child starts crying, does not use his arm, and does not let anybody touch him. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a pulled elbow. 

Pulled elbow or nursemaid's elbow refers to the subluxation of the annular ligament over the radial head. The mechanism of injury is through axial traction on the extended and pronated forearm.  This happens when a child is pulled at the wrist to prevent a fall or is picked up from the floor by the hand.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

 Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin.

Golfer's elbow

 Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin.

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis.

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle.

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action.

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis.

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with progressive swelling of the upper end of the humerus. The X-ray image is given below. CT scan of the chest reveals metastasis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given radiograph shows the sunburst appearance of the tumor at the metaphyseal end of a long bone, which is suggestive of osteosarcoma. 

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on x-ray.

Other options:

Option A - Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor:

The commonly affected age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

 

Option B - Ewing's sarcoma:

It is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years. It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus. 

Radiographic findings: Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

 

Option D - Secondary metastasis from the prostate is typically densely osteosclerotic, in contrast to osteolytic renal and thyroid lesions. Lung and breast metastases produce mixed osteoblastic/osteolytic lesions.

Local and distal staging includes X-rays and MRI of the whole affected bone, bone scintigraphy, and CT scan of thorax, abdomen and pelvis. The most sensitive imaging modality for identifying metastases is the whole-body MRI.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

 Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin.

Golfer's elbow

 Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin.

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis.

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle.

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action.

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis.

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament.

questions.text: In tennis elbow, the primary tendinosis occurs at ______.
questions.solution:
In the tennis elbow, primary tendinosis occurs at 1-2 cm distal to the attachment of extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle to the lateral epicondyle. 

Tennis elbow is also known as lateral epicondylitis. This is the most common tendinopathy. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at lateral epicondyle in activities that require repetitive forceful wrist extension and supination. 

It is common in individuals who play tennis, squash, and badminton. The pain improves on rest.

Conservative management with physiotherapy will speed up the recovery. Steroid injections can be used for short-term pain relief. Arthroscopic surgery technique can be used, but it has a higher risk of nerve injury.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements. 
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension.
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved.

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle. 
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist. 
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in tennis elbow.
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anaesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative.
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle.

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow.

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases.
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: You have been allotted a patient with an upper limb fracture in the orthopedics ward. The patient fell on his elbow and complains of pain on elbow movement. On examining, the 3 bony point relationship is reversed. The examiner gives you xrays as shown below and asks you to pick up the one belonging to the patient.
questions.solution:
The given patient with a fall on the elbow and reversed 3 bony point relationship is likely a case of Olecranon fracture. The x-ray D corresponds to the displaced transverse olecranon fracture.

The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle and the olecranon. When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, they form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line. 

Since supracondylar fracture (X-ray:C) occurs above any of these bony landmarks, the 3 bony point relationship is preserved in this.

Other options:

A - Galleazi fracture 

B - Monteggia fracture

C- Supracondylar fracture

 

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: The appearance of USG at saphenofemoral junction, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:
questions.solution:
The normal anatomy of the femoral vessels and great saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction on USG is called the mickey mouse sign.

The given images below show the mickey mouse sign (FV- femoral vein; FA- femoral artery; GSV- great saphenous vein).

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images are suggestive of intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign- this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. It shows coffee bean sign

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:
questions.solution:
The given IVP depicts the cobra head or adder head deformity or spring onion sign seen in bilateral ureterocele. It refers to dilatation of the distal ureter, surrounded by a thin lucent line seen in adult-type, uncomplicated ureterocoele. 

Ureterocele refers to the congenital dilatation of the distal-most portion of the ureter. The dilated portion of the ureter may herniate into the bladder secondary to an abnormal VUJ (vesicoureteric junction).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with recurrent episodes of blood in his stool. Meckelâ€™s diverticulum is suspected. Which of the following can be used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Tc 99m pertechnetate scanning is used to confirm the diagnosis of Meckel's diverticulum.

Other uses of Tc-99m pertechnetate include:
