questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition marked by morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. Eg: Suspecting a faithful partner of infidelity, with accompanying jealousy.

DELUSIONAL MISIDENTIFICATION SYNDROMES

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli’s syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: A very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppleganger syndrome: A person feels he has his own impostor(duplicate) – Delusion of subjective doubles.

This is a recent AIIMS question. Named delusions and themes of delusions are repeatedly being asked in AIIMS as well as NEET examination. A good understanding of this high yield topic will be helpful.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.solution:
Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase of normal sexual cycle.

Related Pearl: Sexual disorders

Phase
Characteristics
Disorder
Treatment
Desire
Focuses on the patient's drives, motivation, and desires
Hypoactive sexual desire: Patients have a decrease or absence of sexual fantasies, desires, etc
 
Sexual aversion: A complete aversion to all sexual contact
Address issues like feelings of guilt, poor self-esteem, homosexual impulses, etc
 
Couples therapy may be indicated if due to marital conflict
Arousal
Consists of a sense of sexual pleasure with accompanying physiologic changes
Female sexual arousal disorder: Persistent failure to achieve or maintain sufficient sexual interest or arousal during the sexual act
 
Impotence: Persistent or recurrent inability to attain or maintain an adequate erection until completion of the sexual act
Address issues like guilt, anxiety, and fear
 
Check for use of medications that cause vaginal dryness, like antihistamines or anticholinergics
 
Relaxation techniques.
 
Determine if organic or psychological.
 
Consider plethysmography or postage stamp test
Orgasm
Physiologic state in which sexual tension is released and contractions are produced in various organs
Female orgasmic disorder and delayed ejaculation: Recurrent or persistent inability to achieve orgasm either through masturbation or sexual intercourse
 
Premature ejaculation: Ejaculation before the man wishes to do so, before penetration or just after penetration

Address issues of guilt, fear of impregnation, etc

Use vibrators, education, and fantasy

Behavioral techniques such as squeeze and stop-and-go

Address issues of anxiety about the sexual act

SSRIs to delay ejaculation
Pain
Subjective sense of pain associated with the sexual act. Most likely due to dynamic factors
Genito-pelvic pain disorder: Pain associated with sexual intercourse in either male or female. Not diagnosed when the organic cause has been found or if due to vaginal lubrication.
 
Penetration disorder: Involuntary constriction of the outer one-third of the vagina that interferes with the sexual act.

Help with issues of anxiety and tension about the sexual act

Behavioral techniques, such as the use of dilators and relaxation

Address issues of fear of impregnation, strict upbringing, religion, etc

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for her?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from rapid cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year
  • Episodes either have a partial or full remission for atleast 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhea is not a side effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are associated with dry mouth, and not sialorrhea.

System Side effects of SSRIs
Sexual Anorgasmia, Decreased libido
Gastrointestinal ( 5-HT3 receptor) Nausea, Diarrhea, Anorexia, Vomiting, Flatulence, and Dyspepsia
Nervous system Extremely vivid dreams or nightmares, Anxiety, Insomnia/sedation, Seizures, Emotional blunting
Anticholinergic Dry mouth, Constipation, Sedation
Cardiovascular Drug induced long QT syndrome
Hematological Easy bruising
Endocrine Mammoplasia, Galactorrhea

questions.text: The memory disorder correctly matched with the pathology is?

choices.text: Korsakoff syndrome -  hyperactivation of mammillary bodies
Alzheimer's disease - early degeneration of frontal lobe
Frontotemporal dementia - mesial temporal lobe atrophy

questions.solution:
The cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease is due to the loss of synapses and neuronal degeneration.

Microscopically, the following are seen:

  • Neuritic plaques - containing amyloid-β
  • Neurofibrillary tangles - containing abnormally phosphorylated tau proteins
  • Amyloid-β accumulation in the blood vessel walls of the cortex and leptomeninges.

Option A: In Korsakoff syndrome, there is inactivation (not hyperactivation) of mammillary bodies due to thiamine deficiency.

Option C: Alzheimer's disease initially affects the parietal and temporal lobe, followed by the frontal lobe in the later stages. Hence personality changes are a late feature of Alzheimer's. 

Option D: Mesial temporal lobe atrophy is very sensitive for Alzheimer's disease.

World Alzheimer’s Day is an international campaign to raise awareness and highlight issues faced by people affected by dementia, it takes place every year on 21 September. The theme for World Alzheimer's Month in 2020 is "Let's talk about dementia"

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetics does not cause myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, a short-acting I.V. anesthetic agent doesnâ€™t cause myocardial depression.

Etomidate is the mostÂ cardiac stableÂ intravenous agent due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. Hence, etomidate is the I.V. agent of choice in patients withÂ coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, andÂ cerebral vascular disease.

Side effects of Etomidate:

  • The highest incidence of nausea and vomiting among inducing agents
  • Superficial thrombophlebitis and pain on injection
  • Adrenocortical suppression

Note: Although Ketamine has an indirect sympathetic stimulatory effect, itÂ possesses a direct negativeÂ inotropic effect on the myocardium. Hence, ketamine has to be used cautiously in critically ill patients with shock, as they are prone to have a depletion of endogenous catecholamines. Ketamine infusion in such patients can unmask its direct negative inotropic effects and further decrease the blood pressure and cardiac output.

Hence, for this MCQ, Etomidate is the best answer.

questions.text: You are an anesthetist who needs to administer general anesthesia to an obese patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Anticipating a difficult airway, preoperatively you assess the airway using Modified Mallampati classification and conclude that the patient falls under class III. How does her airway probably look?
questions.solution:
The patient’s airway looks like the image in Option 3, which is Mallampati Class III -  soft palate and base of the uvula is seen.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation.

The patient has to be seated, head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only class I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. 

In addition to class I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen on mouth opening and tongue protrusion. However, it is still not proven by studies whether the class 0 is a sign of easy intubation or not. 

Other options-

Option 1 - Mallampati class IV: Soft palate is not visible at all.

Option 2 - Mallampati class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula, and pillars are seen.

Option 4 - Mallampati class II: Soft palate, fauces, and portion of uvula are visible.

 

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • History of snoring
  • Obesity
  • Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  • Previous head and neck radiation
  • Head and neck trauma
  • Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Down syndrome
  • Scleroderma
  • Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  • Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  • Thyromental distance <6.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Increased neck circumference (>17 inches in men or >16 inches in women)
  • Upper lip bite test : Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  • Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting a difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates an ease with intubation.

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen?
questions.solution:
The curare notch in the plateau phase of the capnograph indicates that the patient is trying to breathe spontaneously. The patient's inspiratory effort causes some fresh gas to be sucked in the capnometer, resulting in a lower carbon dioxide concentration and a notch.

Image below shows a capnograph with clefts during phase III which indicates spontaneous breathing efforts by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation. It is also known as a curare notch or cleft.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted.â€¯
Mâ€¯-Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
Nâ€¯-Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression.â€¯
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: You have just performed defibrillation in a patient with ventricular fibrillation. According to the ACLS guidelines, what should be your next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths. This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit the patient by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm or asystole for at least 5 seconds. It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate immediately because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

If after 2 minutes, the rhythm remains the same, then another shock is delivered. Chest compression and rescue breaths are resumed and 1 mg epinephrine is administered. Consideration is given for an advanced airway placement.

If after 2 minutes the rhythm still remains the same, the first dose of amiodarone 300mg bolus is given.

With the next cycle of CPR, a shock is delivered and 1 mg of epinephrine is given. And with the cycle of CPR after that, shock is delivered and the second dose of amiodarone- 150mg is given

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Miller laryngoscopic blade.

Miller is a straight blade laryngoscope, used in:

  • Neonates, infants and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Straight blade, Miller
  • Curved blade, Macintosh

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is ________
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme. The most commonly occurs following a herpes simplex virus infection.

Erythema multiforme is best regarded as a selfâ€limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cellâ€mediated hypersensitivity. It most commonly occurs following an infection or drug intake.

It presents clinically with a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic acral iris or ‘target lesions’.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  1. Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  2. Middle paler zone of edema
  3. Outer ring of erythema with a wellâ€defined edge

Lesions may involve the palms and the trunk. Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions.

The common triggers are:

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives
  • Miscellaneous- lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa

The image below shows target lesions.

questions.text: 24-year-old presents with intensely itchy lesion for three days. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is a ring lesion with a central clearing suggestive of tinea corporis.

Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 

Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge with central resolution. Scaling is a common but not a constant finding. 

Other options:

Option B: Granuloma annulare is a circular lesion with central clearing found most commonly in children and in adult females <30 years. They usually manifest as groups of 1- to 2-mm papules that range in color from skin-colored to violaceous, often in an annular arrangement over distal extremities.

Option C: Ichthyosis Vulgaris presents with dry scaly lesions in infants. Fine scales usually develop on the back and over skin near the knee/elbow joints. Ichthyosis is usually most common and severe over the lower legs.

Option D: Pyoderma gangrenosum, chronic, recurrent, very painful neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders usually found on the lower limbs. It is usually associated with Inflammatory Bowel disease.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is candidal intertrigo.

It is a candidal infection of opposing skin surfaces, which presents as erythema with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold. When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.

As the condition progresses, it spreads beyond the area of contact, usually developing the typical features of candidosis with a fringed, irregular edge and subcorneal pustules rupturing to give tiny erosions, and then further peeling of the stratum corneum.

Treatment:

Topical antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Bowenâ€™s disease?

choices.text: Occasionally it may undergo spontaneous partial resolution

questions.solution:
Bowen's disease has a low potential for invasive malignancy. 

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, nonâ€elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.

Human papilloma virus infection is associated with it.

Image: Red scaly plaque seen on the finger, in an 81-year-old woman with Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with burning pain on passing urine. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient occurring 3 days after unprotected sex point to urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as its incubation period is 1-5 days.

The most common presentation of gonococcal infection in men is acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Pharyngeal and rectal infections can also occur depending on the type of sexual contact.

The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may be involved. Symptoms include excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital and intermenstrual bleeding.

The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia, which has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. It usually presents with dysuria alone, but mucopurulent discharge can occur. Other causes of NGU are Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis.

questions.text: A radiation oncologist uses radiotherapy as part of the treatment protocol for various tumors. This treatment modality is found to be least effective in which among the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is least effective in melanoma as it is a highly radioresistant tumor.

Apoptosis occurs in response to radiation in some but not all cells. No meaningful apoptosis occurs in very radioresistant tumors like melanoma and glioblastoma.

Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors are

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilm’s tumour

 Highly radioresistant tumors are

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.text: What does the ultrasonography transducer contain?
questions.solution: Lead zirconate titanate (PZT) is the most widely used material in the ultrasound transducers/probes. They have replaced the previously used barium titanate.

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of thium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron, if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.

questions.text: Mrs. Kokila presents with a lump in her left breast at 10 weeks of pregnancy. Ultrasound and trucut biopsy revealed the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma. How will you manage this patient?

choices.text: Perform mastectomy and start chemotherapy immediately after delivery
Mastectomy followed by hormonal therapy in the second and third trimester
Mastectomy followed by chemotherapy in the second and third trimester

questions.solution:
A pregnant woman who is diagnosed with breast cancer in first trimester is best managed by mastectomy along with chemotherapy in the second and third trimester.

Pregnancy-associated breast cancer is defined as breast cancer that is diagnosed during pregnancy or within 1 year of postpartum.

It is the most common non-gy­necologic malignancy associated with pregnancy. Most patients present with a painless mass in the breast with or without bloody nipple discharge.

Diagnosis is done by ultrasonography and tissue biopsy.

Treatment of breast cancer in pregnancy:

  • Breast cancer in pregnancy is mainly treated by mastectomy in any trimester along with chemotherapy in the second and third trimesters.
  • Since radiotherapy is a component of breast conservation therapy, it is contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy. However, breast-conserving lumpectomy and axillary lymph node dissection with chemotherapy can be done in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy followed by radiation after delivery. 
  • Radiotherapy and hormonal therapies are absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy because of teratogenicity. They can be initiated after delivery.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy: 
It is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone while
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.
